title: Canada Scraps Digital Tax on US Firms, Trade Talks Resume
snippets: President Trump said Friday that he was suspending trade talks with Canada over its plans to continue with its tax on technology firms, which he called "a direct and blatant attack on our country."
Canada's prime minister says trade talks with US will resume with decision to drop new levy.
After Canada abandoned a planned digital services tax on US tech firms, trade negotiations between Ottawa and Washington are set to resume.

<a href="https://news.google.com/rss/articles/CBMikgFBVV95cUxNai1oZjIzY295N2Faa2Z1RFhvQm9DU0tfaVRnQnpQN0pyWkw2RnhZWnBRN0xraTNCVjhrRkl1Rm5lS3BMZkh0bEMxcUhoajE5LUVlcFNOdXBJSmthQWdEajBtdGtndFFweU1tNGhtVWZqbmFIZkJDT1drdHNNTWxzT1JObmtJX0kyMDhqQ2Vic0Vqdw?oc=5" target="_blank">Canada axes digital services
The move comes after U.S. President Donald Trump announced over the weekend that he will be "terminating ALL discussions on Trade with Canada"
US president had described levy as ‘direct and blatant’ attack on the country
Ottawa said Prime Minister Mark Carney and President Donald Trump had agreed to resume negotiations on a trade agreement and would aim to reach a deal by July 21.
The government said on Sunday night that it would cancel its tax on American technology companies, handing a victory to the Trump administration.

Canada has rescinded its digital services tax in hopes to advance trade negotiations with the U.S., Canada’s finance ministry said in a statement on Sunday. “Rescinding the DST will allow the negotiations to make vital progress and reinforce our work to create jobs and build prosperity fo
titles: Canadian prime minister says U.S. trade talks resume after Canada rescinded tech tax
Canada rescinds digital services tax after Trump suspends trade talks
US, Canada trade talks to resume after digital tax scrapped
Canada axes digital services tax in push to advance trade talks with U.S. - Axios

Canada scraps tech tax to advance Trump trade talks
Canada rescinds digital services tax after Trump suspends trade talks
Canada to Scrap Tax That Led Trump to Suspend Trade Talks
Canada rescinds digital services tax to resume talks with the United States
summary: Canada has canceled its planned digital services tax on U.S. technology firms, a move that comes after President Trump announced he would terminate all trade discussions with Canada due to the proposed levy, which he labeled a "direct and blatant attack" on the U.S. The cancellation of the tax led to the resumption of trade talks between the two nations, with both sides aiming to reach an agreement by July 21. This decision by Canada aims to foster negotiations, job creation, and prosperity, according to Canada's finance ministry.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides actionable insights into the ongoing trade negotiations between Canada and the US, and how the decision to scrap the digital tax could impact these discussions. It also highlights the potential positive outcomes of this decision, such as job creation and prosperity, thus reporting on solutions and improvements.

title: Southern Europe Warns of Major Heat Wave, Urges Safety Measures
snippets: The countries most affected are Italy, Greece, Spain and Portugal, with temperatures nearing or topping 40C (104F).

Health and environmental alerts issued with high temperatures expected in France, Italy, Portugal and Spain

Large parts of Europe continue to be gripped by a heatwave today, with temperatures in mid to high 30s and low 40s Celsius and a range of health and environmental ale
Portugal is expected to see highs of up to 109 degrees Fahrenheit. Parts of Spain, France, Italy and Greece are also bracing for extreme heat.

Authorities across Southern Europe urged people to seek shelter Sunday and protect the most vulnerable as punishing temperatures from Spain to Portugal, Italy and France climbed higher in the summer's first major heat wave.
titles: Wildfire risks as climate change fuels extreme heatwave in Southern Europe

summary: Authorities in Southern Europe, including Spain, Portugal, Italy, and France, warned residents to find shelter and protect vulnerable individuals amid the region's first major heat wave of the summer. High temperatures prompted these advisories, emphasizing the need for safety measures during the extreme weather event.
constructiveness_reason: The story informs readers about the imminent heat wave in Southern Europe and the safety measures that are recommended. It provides useful information for those who might be affected by the heat wave, contributing to their decision-making and sense of agency. However, it does not highlight any long-term solutions or improvements to handle such extreme weather events.

title: Two Firefighters Killed in Idaho Wildfire Ambush; Suspect Found Dead
snippets: Local authorities said a man armed with a rifle started a fire on a mountain in northern Idaho and then began shooting at responding firefighters, killing two and injuring a third.
The suspect has been found dead after the firefighters were killed with a high-powered weapon, authorities say.
Authorities lifted the shelter order after a team of officers found the body of the suspected shooter.
Two firefighters killed, another wounded after armed man ambushed fire crews responding to blaze in Kootenai County.

Two firefighters deployed to a fire near Coeur d'Alene, in the northwestern state of Idaho, have been shot dead in an ambush. The suspected gunman, who is thought to have acted alone, has also been found dead.

<a href="https://news.google.com/rss/articles/CBMihAFBVV95cUxPN1hRNk1jQnNXLUN4VkdoV0U1VnpIZU10RnQ3MmZKRmFVdklrQnFuSjJOZXBFYVFLRlRuZ1FQZGdROVJBYl9vUU43dndiTTJDdDZTZUZDX3F4OUstLVUydjJmaVZxN0FzVUVtTGRXRWt4X3FOZU5pM2dlZzFBRUZoQ2ZoMUE?oc=5" target="_blank">2 dead, officers "taking sniper fire" after atta
Firefighters were ambushed by a gunman while responding to a brush fire in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, on Sunday, according to the local sheriff's office.

Police find body of suspect, who they said started the fire intentionally to ambush first responders

A man armed with a rifle intentionally started a wildfire and then began shooting at first responders in a northern Idaho mountain community, killing two firefighters and wounding a third du
Police lifted a shelter-in-place order in Coeur d’Alene after a man with a firearm was found dead near the shooting location.

summary: In Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, two firefighters were killed and another was injured after being ambushed by a gunman who had intentionally started a wildfire on a mountain. The suspect, armed with a high-powered rifle, targeted the first responders as they arrived to combat the blaze. Authorities later found the suspect dead, leading to the lifting of a shelter-in-place order in the area. The incident occurred near Coeur d'Alene, with local law enforcement and emergency teams responding to the tragic event.
constructiveness_reason: While this story does provide basic awareness about a tragic event, it lacks depth or insight that could be useful to the reader. It does not report on any solutions or improvements, nor does it increase clarity around systems, causes, trends, or impacts that matter.

title: Guatemala Beats Canada in Penalties to Reach Gold Cup Semifinals
snippets: Jose Morales buried the winner in the seventh round of penalty kicks to propel Guatemala over Canada and into the semifinals of the Concacaf Gold Cup on Sunday in Minneapolis.
Canada have only been to the Gold Cup semifinals once since 2009 and fell well short this year

Jesse Marsch speaks to the media following Canada’s penalty loss to Guatemala, addresses Jacob Shaffelburg’s two yellow cards, how a poor second half sank their Gold Cup hopes, and how this team needs to learn from this loss.

Watch as Jose Morales clinches a stunning victory for Guatemala in the Gold Cup quarterfinal, knocking home a penalty kick in the shootout to knock off Canada and send Guatemala to their first semifinal at the competition since 1996.

Damion Downs scored in the sixth round of a shootout after three saves by Matt Freese, sending the U.S. to the semifinals of the Concacaf Gold Cup with a 4-3 penalty-kicks win over Costa Rica after a a 2-2 tie on Sunday night.
titles: Guatemala dumps Canada in Gold Cup shootout
Canada stunned in Gold Cup quarterfinals as Guatemala make semis for first time since 1996
‘We beat ourselves’: Marsch wants Canada to learn from Gold Cup loss
Guatemala’s Morales delivers penalty strike to stun Canada at Gold Cup
U.S. gets past Costa Rica in Gold Cup quarterfinals on penalty kicks
summary: Guatemala advanced to the CONCACAF Gold Cup semifinals for the first time since 1996 after defeating Canada in a penalty shootout, 6-5, following a 1-1 draw. José Morales scored the decisive penalty for Guatemala. Canada's Gold Cup journey ended in the quarterfinals, marking another year since their last semifinal appearance in 2009. Jesse Marsch, addressing the media, highlighted the need for the Canadian team to learn from their defeat.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the outcome of a significant soccer match and the implications for the teams involved. It also offers some context, highlighting the historical significance of the result for both teams. However, it does not report on any solutions or improvements, nor does it provide a deeper understanding of the systems or trends in play.
